Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Comment: Before the hunt, they should not swear using e.g. words for private parts women/men, otherwise an accident will happen. Nuno = 4 days before the hunt starts they say a kind of prayer and offer food and drink to ancestors so that the hunt will go well. When the hunt starts, they do Lɜgɜ' (= to press): They put money tobacco and silk on the biggest rock / under the biggest tree as an offering so that the hunt will go well.

Feature: Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: There are some parallellisms, e.g. the word to propose marriage (see above)

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: There is not really a separate ritual language. Everyone can understand the language that is used in rituals.

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Are there ritual dances?
Comment: Liã = half circle dance, also the name of the song accompanying it, and a mantra. Sole = full circle dance, also the name of the song accompanying it.

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Comment: Some young people that have stayed in the village know it; young people that have studied or worked elsewhere, don't know it.

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Do women and men dance together?
Comment: Sili' = war dance, only for men. Hedũ and Sole Liã for women and men (to find a partner), Gawe Au ('step bamboo'): only for women. (In Solor the men can also dance this.)

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: Yes there is one dance where they are separated. When they do ann offering in the corner of the rumah adat, women are not allowed to come in.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: Ceremony Pa'o Bani is before planting and harvesting. (pa'o = feed, bani = altar)

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: Called Kelaki Ado Pehã from Lembata.

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: see above

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: The rumah adat, and the altar noba nara, and the square in front of the rumah adat Namã (= kind of dance, other name for Sole dance).

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Comment: They were sitting on the back of a crocodile using it as a boat. Adonara people have a special relation with elephants: they will never harm anyone from Adonara, and when an Adonara person talks to them, they will listen when they get an offering. They should not be killed.

Feature: Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: The ancestor man came from a mountain in Lembata and the woman from a mountain in Adonara.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: They are called kebe'le = big.

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: arak, tuak, sirih pinang, tobacco. (Honey, marak = tuak from coconut, drank when people are sick.)

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: Called Nubo Nara

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: But there is the ritual 4 days after birth (see above).

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: 4 days after a person dies and is buried, the family is baptized with coconut oil and they get a blessing from one of the elders in the family. This is called Toto Dulat.

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: When they hear a civet cat (defender of the clan) crying it means the ancestors need food. They offer chicken and rice to the ancestors/saints (Nuba Nara) and to Rera Wula (sun moon) (= God?) on the Pa'o Nuba Nara = altar. This ritual is also done before they build the rumah adat.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Is there traditional pottery?
Comment: In Lemat no pottery is produced but in Lamakera in Solor they make pottery. (Kera = bucket to fetch water from the well.)

Feature: Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: Gambus (guitar), Gõ Bawa (gong drum); played e.g. when a new rumah adat is build.

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: Not special for this village.

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: With hard rock from the sea (not corral rock)

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Comment: Long hair for men bound on top of the head with a knot on top of it.

Feature: Traditional piercings?
Comment: Gola: round earrings of besi putih for guys to wear in the ears. Not practiced anymore. Nowadays only women have earrings.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: Nile bala (ivory), nile kasido, nile tana; nile = necklace. Coconut leaves used like a crown (for men) called Kenobo, with Senai (slendang).

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: See above

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: see above

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: north: rai, west: lali, east: teti, south: lau. In Witi Hama, a village on the other side of the mountain, south: rai, east: teti, west: lali, north: lau. So the directional system is directed towards the mountain, not absolute.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Comment: there is a tree called Kepara, which has two genders: male and female. The wood of the female is used for a ritual to sweep a grave every day after the burrial, till the ceremony on day 4.

Feature: Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Lamaholot, B Indonesia, B Malayu

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: B Indonesia, B Malayu, Lamaholot

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: Use Lamaholot, or language of the other

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: If the wife is not from here she must learn Lmh

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: If the husband is not from here, he learns Lmh

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: In the beginning they may use Indonesian or Melayu as intermediate language

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: During musim kemarau (May-Oct) with dogs, using bow and arrow, and machete

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: With a large net that is left in the sea for several days

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: pig, goat, chicken (no cows)

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: Mostly 1-6 km from the village

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Comment: Corn (only Oct-Jan), cassava, beans, coconut; fruits: banana, mangga, papaya.

Feature: Major crops?
Comment: Mostly corn, coconut and mangoes

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: In Lewat there are 5 clans: Sanga Na'e, Gede Na'e, Lia Na'e, Lasã Na'e, Atamuki. (Bpk Kerung is from Atamuki.)

Feature: Are there moieties?
Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: Each clan has its own traditional house.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: The highest one is Gede Na'e, the remaining 4 are equal in rank. Gede Na'e has the kepala kampung, which is like a president of all the clans. Each of the other clans have their own leader (ketua suku). Gede Na'e may be the leading clan because they were the first to migrate from Ria Wale in the mountains to Niha One and then to Lewat.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Comment: Land is considered the mother = source of life.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: Kepala kampung = Lawo Alate (lawo 'kampung', alate 'owner') is the tuan tanah.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: Sawah/field/garden: divided between the sons. Rumah adat (if father is kepala suku): the title and the house goes to the eldest son. Ivory goes to eldest son. Kain tenun divided between sons and daughters (daughters optional). In general the youngest son gets the least and daughters do not inherit.

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: Women are excluded. They become part of the clan of their husband. That clan receives the belis.

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Comment: Only kain tenun, optional, if there are enough of them.

Feature: Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: Newcomers cannot buy garden, cannot buy land to build a house. Land belongs to the original people as the source of their life. Newcomers are only allowed a temporary house, and cannot join traditional ceremonies except marriage.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: 20-30 men (most around 24); 16-28 women (most around 18) In the 1970's it was the custom that men married between 30-40+, women 20-30+. Now it is 20+ for men, 15+ for women.The reason that the age was higher earlier may be the price of the belis, and the fact that man and woman could already live together without being married in church.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: 1. Certain clans do not marry each other (not in Lewat but in neighbouring villages). If it happens the belis is not paid. Types of marriage: Gete-Dahã 'ask-ask': ask for woman, proper way. Pɜla'e: Kawin lari, marriage without parent's permission. Bɜluwo: forced marriage because woman is pregnant. Bote: Woman is kidnapped (because she doesn't agree; her parents may or may not agree.) This is the worst way to get married and it is no longer practised.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: In church they exchange rings. But they do not exchange food/drink.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: There is no bride service but if belis is not yet paid, it is utang, and the debt will remain and be inherited by the children.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: Wife moves to husband's group always, even if the bridewealth is not yet paid.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
Comment: It is possible to marry inside the clan (if not kaka adik) as well as outside the clan. Breũ can be married outside, but also someone from a different clan. Cousins cannot be married.

Feature: If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: Paternal/maternal grandparents can both raise the children.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: Breũ (cousin that is the child of mother's brother) principle. Mother's brother (opu lake) is most highly respected, as the provider of the mother (=life), and the person to whom belis is paid.

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Comment: It happens but less so.

Feature: Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: Ivory, goat, pig, chicken; It's called weli̚

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: Kain, bracelets. It called Ohe.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Comment: Related men tend to live closer to each other.

Feature: Mean size of local communities?
Comment: 4 desa in area Dua Nukin; Lewat, Nia One, Bunga Lawa, Beda Lawon.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: yes

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: Village square, called Basa for each village. In addition there is a space called Sebaõ for many desa; and a Pasang Grahan, a kind of court.

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Floor level of traditional houses?
Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Comment: west-east are steaper than north-south

Feature: Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: There is a new tradition where they do build an attic.

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Are leaders non-hereditary?
Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Comment: no

Feature: Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: There is a famous war called Paji-Demõ, two regions in Ile Bolɛ that fight about borders. They were arch enemies till the 1960's

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: The shape of the village is typically that the head of the village is in the direction of the mountain whereas the foot of the village is in the direction of the sea. This might be related to the fact that they believe the original settlement was on the mountain and they migrated away from it. There is one village that has the opposite direction: head towards the sea, feet towards the mountain.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there men’s houses
Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: Hereditary

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: Earlier there were slaves but not anymore. Whether they were hereditary or not we don't know.

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: Nayu' Baya: treaty to not have war between villages (not clans). Some villages are considered brothers, e.g. Watu Waĩ and Tapu Bale. No barter trade relations. Ivory bought in Tanjung Bunga.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Comment: Nayu' Baya: treaty to not have war between villages (not clans).

Feature: Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: A baby gets a temporary name (Kopõ Wulã for boy, Sedõ Gurek for girl) for 2-3 days to 1 week, then there is a Golɛ ̃ Lala (sit in a circle- porridge). This ceremony is only held if a child is born at home with a traditional midwife (dukun). Not when it is born in hospital.
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: Not in Lewat, but there is one clan (Dosin Na'ɛ ̃) that owns two names that cannot be used elsewhere.

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: First child gets father's family name, the second and third gets either father's or mother's family name. it is a family name, not the name of the clan.

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Comment: For second or third child, optional.

Feature: Are there name taboos?
Comment: You should not use the names from clan Dosin Na'ɛ .

Feature: Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
Comment: Father and mother and Opu must not be called by their first name.

Feature: did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: Koda Kiwãne (koda = word, message)

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: Murike. Derived from the word murĩ 'new'.
